task.summary:
1. Added Basic GameUI: One scene for the initial game configuration form One scene for the in game (player bars, map, global chat log)
2. Added Procedural Map Generation logic based on PerlinNoise algorithm

1. Added Basic GameUI: One scene for the initial game configuration form One scene for the in game (player bars, map, global chat log)
2. Added Procedural Map Generation logic based on PerlinNoise algorithm

1. Removed the excess of static context 2. GameUI class now uses the generic methods "setupElement" in order to position specific Node Elements/set sizes for specific Region elements 3. A lot of code refactoring

1. Removed the excess of static context 2. GameUI class now uses the generic methods "setupElement" in order to position specific Node Elements/set sizes for specific Region elements 3. A lot of code refactoring

More UI & Map Logic changes
1. The map drawing inside it's layout should had not a FIXED size in pixels, it was depending on the dimension of the noiseMatrix resulted from the Map Pane's width/height (in pixels) divided into the variable tileSize selected before. Considering the old resolution for map was: 1280*900, for example, 3 does not divide 1280 or 7 does not divide 900! We would like to keep the tileSizes in pixels like that. Solution: Map Pane's (in pixels) should be choosen in such way that it will be able to be EXACTLY divided by each of the tileSizes in pixels: 3,4,5,6,7 (depending on the map type selected before). So we are doing the least common multiple of (3,4,5,6,7)=420 -> a close resolution of 1260*840(3:2 aspect ratio) for the Map Pane should work fine for the 1600x900 window size we test on. Soon we will have a responsive update for >=720p monitors. Why? Doing so we'll have noiseMatrix's width=1260/tileSize and height=840/tileSize (both INTEGER numbers, better than doubles). Why? An unexact division with the tileSizes would result in a double width and height, that must be converted into int in order to be the number of columns/rows in the matrixes. Conversion Double to Int would result in precision loss and different sizes for the mapPane's when drawn. Bad example, tilesize=7: 1280/7=182.8571428571429 -> converted to 182 and 900/7 -> 128.5714285714286 converted to 128 now multiplying those by the tile drawing size we have 182*7=1274 and 128*7=896 a totally different resolutions than the one we chose!
2. Few Changes to the UI: added more containers for easy alignment. Following commit will be more focused on this part.

New introUI & graphics using CSS
The introUI was totally remaked using layouts. The structure is done via Java Code, while the graphics is now styled with an external css. This allows separation of the UI structure/graphics, but also permits flexibility for the game's graphics, as long as it fits to the structure in the java code.

New introUI & graphics using CSS
The introUI was totally remaked using layouts. The structure is done via Java Code, while the graphics is now styled with an external css. This allows separation of the UI structure/graphics, but also permits flexibility for the game's graphics, as long as it fits to the structure in the java code.
Added out folder for .class files and res folder for the resources
Added ImageLoader class, used for processing the Icons for the MapEtities in the UI

Updates to the InGameUI
-InGame interface now looks nice. -Added RESET button, that will take the user back to the intro scene and reconfigure the game settings.

Updates to Map
-Map in the inGameUI is now Zoomable, Pannable. -Further performance optimizations for Large/Giant maps coming soon

Observer pattern & Threading features -Added event broadcasters & captures via observer pattern. Their role is to offer SYNCHRONIZED updates to the ingameUI considering the on-the-fly state of the game object; Further events broadcasters/capturers coming soon. -Threading for loading the UI faster. -Players now implement runnable and will have soon their infinite loop ongoing in their run() -Hitting BEGIN button will trigger the Game begin() method, that will spawn the players and start their threads

1. Added Basic GameUI: One scene for the initial game configuration form One scene for the in game (player bars, map, global chat log)
2. Added Procedural Map Generation logic based on PerlinNoise algorithm

1. Added Basic GameUI: One scene for the initial game configuration form One scene for the in game (player bars, map, global chat log)
2. Added Procedural Map Generation logic based on PerlinNoise algorithm ...

1. Removed the excess of static context 2. GameUI class now uses the generic methods "setupElement" in order to position specific Node Elements/set sizes for specific Region elements 3. A lot of code refactoring

More UI & Map Logic changes
1. The map drawing inside it's layout should had not a FIXED size in pixels, it was depending on the dimension of the noiseMatrix resulted from the Map Pane's width/height (in pixels) divided into the variable tileSize selected before. Considering the old resolution for map was: 1280*900, for example, 3 does not divide 1280 or 7 does not divide 900! We would like to keep the tileSizes in pixels like that. Solution: Map Pane's (in pixels) should be choosen in such way that it will be able to be EXACTLY divided by each of the tileSizes in pixels: 3,4,5,6,7 (depending on the map type selected before). So we are doing the least common multiple of (3,4,5,6,7)=420 -> a close resolution of 1260*840(3:2 aspect ratio) for the Map Pane should work fine for the 1600x900 window size we test on. Soon we will have a responsive update for >=720p monitors. Why? Doing so we'll have noiseMatrix's width=1260/tileSize and height=840/tileSize (both INTEGER numbers, better than doubles). Why? An unexact division with the tileSizes would result in a double width and height, that must be converted into int in order to be the number of columns/rows in the matrixes. Conversion Double to Int would result in precision loss and different sizes for the mapPane's when drawn. Bad example, tilesize=7: 1280/7=182.8571428571429 -> converted to 182 and 900/7 -> 128.5714285714286 converted to 128 now multiplying those by the tile drawing size we have 182*7=1274 and 128*7=896 a totally different resolutions than the one we chose!
2. Few Changes to the UI: added more containers for easy alignment. Following commit will be more focused on this part.

New introUI & graphics using CSS
The introUI was totally remaked using layouts. The structure is done via Java Code, while the graphics is now styled with an external css. This allows separation of the UI structure/graphics, but also permits flexibility for the game's graphics, as long as it fits to the structure in the java code.
Added out folder for .class files and res folder for the resources
Added ImageLoader class, used for processing the Icons for the MapEtities in the UI

Updates to the InGameUI
-InGame interface now looks nice. -Added RESET button, that will take the user back to the intro scene and reconfigure the game settings.

Updates to Map
-Map in the inGameUI is now Zoomable, Pannable. -Further performance optimizations for Large/Giant maps coming soon

Observer pattern & Threading features -Added event broadcasters & captures via observer pattern. Their role is to offer SYNCHRONIZED updates to the ingameUI considering the on-the-fly state of the game object; Further events broadcasters/capturers coming soon. -Threading for loading the UI faster. -Players now implement runnable and will have soon their infinite loop ongoing in their run() -Hitting BEGIN button will trigger the Game begin() method, that will spawn the players and start their threads
